explanation:
Correct calculation:  
\( 2 \, \text{km}^2 = 2 \times (1000 \, \text{m})^2 = 2 \times 1{,}000{,}000 \, \text{m}^2 = 2{,}000{,}000 \, \text{m}^2 \)

Student's error:  
\( 2 \, \text{km}^2 = 2 \times 1000 \, \text{m}^2 = 2000 \, \text{m}^2 \)

The student applied the linear conversion factor (1000 m = 1 km) directly to squared units without squaring the conversion factor. This caused them to multiply by 1000 instead of \( 1000^2 \), reducing the result by a factor of 1000. 

The error stems from treating area conversion as equivalent to length conversion, ignoring the dimensionality of the units. This matches the misconception of using a length scale factor for area without squaring it. 

Distinction from related misconceptions:  
The error isn't due to cubing (which would produce \( 1000^3 \)), nor a misunderstanding of metric relationships (they correctly used 1 km = 1000 m). The mistake specifically lies in failing to square the conversion factor for area.
